title: Brexit: Labour warn of 'consequences' for MPs who back Boris Johnson's deal
text:

Labour have warned of 'consequences' for MPs who back Boris Johnson's Brexit deal in a historic showdown tomorrow.

Up to a dozen or so are thought to be considering backing the pact in the House of Commons to - in the PM's words - "get Brexit done".

But Labour sources and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell today refused to rule out suspending the whip for those who defy Jeremy Corbyn to back the deal.

Mr Corbyn has blasted the deal as "worse than Theresa May's", warning it waters down commitments on workers' rights and creates a customs border down the Irish Sea.

Mr McDonnell told the BBC: "This is a three-line whip and the chief whip, in the normal way, will determine the consequences for anyone who doesn't vote for it."

Asked what those consequences might be, he replied: "I'm not the chief whip thank goodness; I've got enough on my plate."

(Image: Leon Neal)

A Labour source refused to confirm or deny what consequences might occur if MPs back the "sell-out" deal.

Mr McDonnell warned he'd "have a chat'' with deal-backing MP Ronnie Campbell to beg him: "Please do not give Boris Johnson this power."

"I'm going to have a chat with Ronnie because he is a good socialist and all his life he has fought alongside me to protect trade union rights and develop trade union rights," he said.

"On this one I'm going to have a chat with him and point out to him: please do not give this power (to weaken workers' rights) to Boris Johnson because you know what he'll do.

"He'll undermine trade union rights. Boris Johnson and those Tory MPs that populate the Cabinet, these are the extreme right who have attacked trade unions throughout their political careers."

(Image: Flying Colours/Getty Images)

He added: "No MP, as far as I'm concerned, who has the true interest of their constituents at heart can allow that to happen."

A Labour source also confirmed to the Mirror that some members of Labour's ruling National Executive Committee have discussed ideas like barring deal-backing MPs from standing again in an election.

However, sources insisted the idea was only in informal discussion among some members of the NEC and stressed it had not been tabled formally. MPs would also be ineligible to stand anyway if the whip was suspended.

It comes as Boris Johnson today launches a frantic charm offensive in a bid to get his Brexit deal passed in the House of Commons.

The Prime Minister returned from Brussels in the early hours to start persuading MPs to back the agreement tomorrow - despite having a majority of minus 45.

MPs will hold their first Saturday sitting since the Falklands War in 1982 after the Prime Minister's new pact was backed by 27 other EU leaders last night.

In a boost to the PM, ousted Tory Oliver Letwin today said 17 or 18 of the 21 Tories who lost the whip last month were likely to back the deal in the House of Commons.

But key ally Dominic Raab admitted it will be "tight" after 10 DUP MPs vowed to vote against - and warned they will be encouraging Tory Brexiteers to do the same.

That will force the Prime Minister to rely on Labour votes if he is to have any hope of getting the deal through in Saturday's historic vote.
description: John McDonnell refused to rule out suspending the whip from MPs who back the PM - as he begged them "please do not give Boris Johnson this power"
